name: A Lunar Odyssey
description: This is the moon mission! You have to build a rocket, make it to the moon, and survive long enough to claim the quest reward. Actually getting back to the planet is optional, but recommended. You should look at the starting quests and figure out how to complete them ASAP. It will require generating lots of compressed metals in a metal compressing machine.

quests.name: To The Moon!
quests.description: Let's go to the moon! Assume you have fueled up the rocket, made your parachute, dropped the rocket on a pad, AND tanked some oxygen, then let's go for it! Right-click on that rocket, and hit the space bar. If it complains about something, STRONGLY CONSIDER PAYING ATTENTION. You can override by hitting space bar again. It will start a 20-second countdown, and you will launch. A destination selection screen will appear. Double-click on the Overworld, then select the moon. You then click the launch button and it will take you there. It will then deploy the lunar lander. You will want to hold down the space bar for reverse thrust so you don't smack into the moon!

tasks.longDescription: Well, before lifting off, I heavily recommend bringing along an energy cell and your fuel loader. You will have to fuel the ship for the return trip when you're on the moon itself! If you set up teleporters, then you don't even have to do this. Another point: you have to carefully land the lunar module. If you don't spend some fuel using the spacebar to pad out your descent, you will not so much land on the moon as blast into the side of it!

quests.name: Rocket Man
quests.description: Well here it is . . . the rocket. Stop by here after you build it to get some prizes!

tasks.longDescription: You can see the recipe for it if you search for "tier 1" in the bottom search bar from the inventory screen. You are going to need to compress a lot of metal!

quests.name: Rocket Manufacturing
quests.description: You will have to build a NASA workbench to build the rocket. It comes with plans for the first-tier rocket that you need to get to the moon.

quests.name: Give Me Some Air Here!
quests.description: Ummm, there isn't much air on the moon. Did you think about that? You are going to need an oxygen mask. You might notice a slot for that near your armor in your inventory. You are also going to need some full oxygen tanks for that mask. For the short duration of your mission, lights tanks will do.

tasks.longDescription: Note: To make the oxygen cannister, you'll need cactus green die. You don't actually need to find a cactus. You can blend yellow and blue dies. You can get these from dandelions and bluebells.

quests.name: Rolling Sheet Metal
quests.description: You are going to need sheet metal for various components on the way to this moon mission. You will have to start with the press, and then start rolling the sheets.

tasks.longDescription: The compressor is powered by coal/charcoal. You will have to feed it some to run it. Run some steel ingots through it to get a sheet. Then start running lots of bronze, aluminum, iron, tin, and more steel through it. You need lots of this stuff. Build another compressor! Build two more after that!

quests.name: Getting Back Safely
quests.description: You did plan to get back from the moon, right? You're going to need a parachute when you get back to the atmosphere!

quests.name: Wafer Madness!
quests.description: To get started on the trip to the moon, you are going to have to make some silicon wafers. The ones for the moon mission require a circuit fabricator. You will also need silicon ore from the deeper recesses of the Overworld. They can be hard to find; the ore looks like coal, but it's a different shade of gray.

tasks.longDescription: I should mention that the fabricator can only be powered from its left side. Galacticraft machines are really fond of this for some bizarre reason.

quests.name: Fueling The Rocket
quests.description: How did you plan to get to the moon without any fuel? Run some oil through this refinery to make fuel. You'll have to then pump it into the rocket right on the pad. You know, I thought rockets ran on hydrogen and oxygen mixes, but apparently in Galcticraft, they run off of petroleum products.

tasks.longDescription: Note: The refinery has to be placed UNDER a source of power. Don't look at me like that. I didn't do it! Also, you want to bring the fuel loader with you to the moon with an energy cell. You need that to refuel the rocket in the lander for getting back!

quests.name: Launchpad
quests.description: The rocket can't launch on any old thing. You have to set up a launch platform. Make nine of these things and set them up for a 3x3 square on the ground. Ummm... do that somewhere where you have a clear view of the sky.

quests.name: A Cheesy Ore
quests.description: Yes, the moon is made of cheese! You can eat it too! To mine it, you need a diamond-level pickaxe, which you definitely should have at this time. That is some hard cheese! You want to have the fortune modifier on your tool if you want to improve your yield of cheese curds. This material is used in sparing amounts for super-advanced technology later in the game, so you do want to pick up some of it.

tasks.longDescription: I did not improve the ore generation rate on the moon, so be prepared for a grind here. You will probably readily find this stuff with mining automation. Failing that, get yourself a good oxygen supply and a Tinkers' Construct hammer. Just drop down a little under ground and go off in some direction until you trip across the stuff.

Okay, the Orion Drive requires the ore block, not the cheese itself. This is some funny business here! You will need a tool with silk touch to harvest that. The easiest way to do that is to make a silky gem and mount that on a pick of your choice. There is another quest that goes through in detail (the "Divide By Diamond" questline in Bear Grylls' Poop Menu). Some mining automation can also handle it.

quests.name: When Earth Attacks!
quests.description: Let's take this one step further and go to Mars! You will need that Tier 2 rocket. At this point, you should have a good handle on the pre-launch checklist, but I still heavily recommend packing along teleportation equipment. This new rocket still only needs one bucket of fuel.

tasks.longDescription: Landing on Mars is no big deal. You'll be covered in protected balloons so you don't have to play the lunar lander game again. That pile of balloons will include a takeoff pad and spare rocket to get you back to the Overworld. It won't include a parachute, a fuel loader, or spare fuel beyond what it didn't eat from its original reserve.
The moon has cheese. Mars has desh ore. You will need a bit of this too in order to advance to the next tier of technology.

quests.name: A Tier In My Eye
quests.description: You made a tier 1 rocket to get to the moon. You need a tier 2 rocket if you want to go to Mars. How do you make a tier 2 rocket? There are two main obstacles, and they are both *tedious!* First, you need tier 2 plans. You will have to find a moon dungeon, kill the guardian, and get the plans out of a chest. That assumes the chest you crack open has the plans. You normally might have to do this a few times! However, there is a merchant in Baby's First Space City that can exchange plans for you. Second, you have to haul in some meteoric iron from the meteors showing up all over the moon. Between all that, you can put the tier 2 rocket together with most of the tooling you already have.

tasks.longDescription: I am not holding your hand as much any more since you're getting into advanced territory here. You do want to do that battle at least once. However, I should mention that there is a merchant in Baby's First Space City that can help you out if you get multiple copies of the buggy plans or something.

The plating you need is created by pressing tier 1 heavy-duty plates with a plate of meteoric iron. You need 8 of these to form the frame. Get all your Mars base stuff ready--especially the teleporters!

Now you can slap that plan in a NASA workbench and start putting it together. You've been through this routine before, so I'm not going through all the details. Just note where the pieces are different this time.

quests.name: The Outer Ring Of My Patience
quests.description: Outside the range of Mars is the asteroid belt. Galacticraft kind of ends there at the moment when it comes to interesting things to do. You can go flying around to all the planets and moons, but there isn't anything much happening there. The asteroid belt is it, and it's only interesting because you can deploy the astro miner there. You'll need a tier 3 rocket to make this happen. At this point, you should be mostly familiar with the ritual, so I'm being very terse about all this.

tasks.longDescription: More plans. This time, you're going for Mars dungeons. You'll find holes in the ground for these too. They are guarded by a giant, mutant creeper that launches TNT at you. You have to bounce them back at the creeper to kill it. I would recommend going to The Nether to practice rebound ghast fireballs before you commit to this fight. On a server, this is especially true because you want to know what kind of lag you're up against. If you are good at this, the creeper boss is actually easier than that crazy skeleton you fought on the moon. Note that you might do this fight a few times, and if you are having bad luck with finding plans, you can trade them in at Baby's First Space City's shops.

More plates. More clanging and banging. These plates are annoying to make. You need to go through three levels of plates, starting with that basic heavy-duty plate, then baking in meteoric iron, then the desh metal. Guhhhhhh...

Alright, throw it all together . . . eventually. Now, don't forget the usual stuff about fuel, parachutes, teleporters, and the like. At this point, I'm not your mom so I'm not going into all the details any more. You got this far so you must know what you're doing. Just don't get cocky like all those other rocket jockeys!

quests.name: A Buggy In My Eye
quests.description: Moving around on the moon can get pretty tedious. If you want to rip around the moonscape, then you need a buddy--err a buggy. I mean, it's more likely to survive driving around on the moon than a horse! This is an advanced quest. You have to do the whole moon dungeon thing and get the plans for one. Honestly, you've seen enough with making these rockets that I trust you. So if you find the plans, I'll give you a buggy. You'll have to set up a 3x3 grid of buggy fueling pads, with a fuel loader off to one side. That needs power and some fuel. Slap the buggy on the pad, and it will load up with fuel. Then you can zip around! Make car sounds, because there isn't enough air on the moon for the buggy to make car noises for you!

tasks.longDescription: This is like the tier 2 plans quest. You have to find a hole in the ground, fall down in there, and get into a fight with a really goofy skeleton. I recommend bringing advanced armor and weapons, and maybe some health/regeneration boosts. Enderium weapons will make this stupidly easy. Remember that you can exchange extra rocket plans for buggy plans in a shop in Baby's First Space City!

quests.name: Hold On There, Buddy
quests.description: You can keep going with the rocket and fly off to the moon safely with the following quests. However, it's actually kind of boring! I'm not going to kid you there. To make it more enjoyable, there are a few quests I'm gating here so you can tell if it's really worth your time. First, you want to investigate making some kind of teleporter. The "A Philadelpha Experiment" chapter has lots of ways to handle all this. With teleportation, you can whisk back and forth from the Overworld to the Moon without making any more rockets.

quests.name: All Systems Go!
quests.description: If you made it here, you have completed requirements from other quests that will make your trip to the moon more fruitful. That means being able to teleport back and forth to/from the moon at the least.

quests.name: Moving In With The Lunatics
quests.description: So, you want a moon base. All the cool kids have one, right? Do you think you're cool enough for one? Let's find out! THIS IS GOING TO BE SOME FUSSY STUFF. Galacticraft is very picky about making sure your base is sealed and filled with oxygen. Only certain blocks register as sealed. Modpack authors can configure this to allow more blocks, but they usually don't, so I didn't either. We're going to stick with blocks that are known to be safe generally. This first quest will be to get the basic materials.

tasks.longDescription: This is going to require quite a pile of tin plates! Fortunately, one plate to one stone yields four of these blocks. So you don't even have to start with a full stack of them. It just means rolling out more metal. CLANG... CLANG... CLANG...
"Quite Clear Glass" is sealable. You don't need glass, but it's really nice to be able to look outside your moonbase and see all the stuff that is trying to kill you!

quests.name: It's Not *That* Advanced
quests.description: You could technically drag a furnace generator up to the moon with you, but that somehow doesn't have the, "atmosphere," if you know what I mean. Oh come on, I'm joking about not being able to combust things on the moon. Actually, the stupid machines work fine, but it just doesn't seem appropriate. If you want the safest, yet convincing method, then use the Advanced Solar Generators in Galacticraft. I should warn you though: these machines kind of stink. You need four of them to consistently power the base. I'll guide you through making one and give you the other three. You also need an energy cell or battery to store the power they generate so you have some when it gets dark.

tasks.longDescription: Yeap, it's about time we did more stupid stuff with diamonds. I mean, really, diamonds. This is three diamonds' worth of waste.
Three of those wafers makes you one module, and you need six modules to make a panel.
...Six modules for a panel.
Finally! Galacticraft likes it's multistep recipes, I'm telling you!

quests.name: Canary In The Moon Mine
quests.description: While working on all this oxygen business, you might want to be able to tell from a distance if your base is sealed and filled with happy, tasty, oxygen. This detector will help with that. It will emit a redstone signal when everything is A-OK. You can connect a lamp or something up to it for a signal.

tasks.longDescription: This does come in handy when first setting up stuff. You are busy trying to figure out if all the fiddly bits are working and POOF! The light turns on!

quests.name: Paying The Piper
quests.description: You better just prepare a pile of power and oxygen piping. It's really annoying to run low and have to get "clever"--in other words, "messy."

tasks.longDescription: 32 Oxygen pipes, pronto.

Thermal Dynamics fluxducts technically connect to Galacticraft machines, but I have noticed glitches connecting the solar panels to the machines with them. It is safer to use Galacticraft's own aluminum wires to connect the panels to some cell/capacitor, and run fluxduct from there. So, 32 aluminum wires. I'll reimburse you on the wool.

quests.name: Locking On
quests.description: You'll want to safely enter and exit your moon base without the atmosphere inside tearing out and causing a ruckus. Honestly, it doesn't do anything cool like that, but that's what it would be like if you didn't have a proper airlock in real life! You need a pair of these. I'm asking you to build one and I'm giving you the second one. This is just enough to build a frame that a 1x2 object--namely you--can walk through.

tasks.longDescription: The airlock frame blocks will be layed two on top of each other to each side of you, one above, and one below. But wait, that would be six blocks! Well, one will be the controller, so you only need five . . .

One piece of the airlock must be the controller. Right-click it in place to tell it when to open and close. I recommend setting it to react to somebody being within 1m of it. Then it's hands-free, baby! Note: Crafting this requires meteoric iron plates. This means you have to already have been on the moon a little bit. This is one reason having a teleportation system back to your Overworld base is very convenient!

quests.name: What? What?!!
quests.description: Sound does not transmit in a vacuum, and the moon pretty much is one. You need a frequency module to pick up on acoustics. This is useful to hear that creeper about to blow you up outside of your spaceship!

tasks.longDescription: Check for the Galacticraft tab where you put your other Galacticraft gear. There should be a slot specifically for this module.

quests.name: Smitten With Meteors
quests.description: Let's just be blunt here. Meteoric iron is something that Galacticraft threw in to try to slow down the progression. It requires a bit of a grind, I will grant you that. It means you have to at least get to the moon first--and Mars later--to harvest this material for advanced equipment. To find this stuff, you have to look for meteors on the surface of the body you're on. Bodies with atmosphere like the Overworld will never spawn them. Look first for brown objects that you can bust with a pick. If you touch those, they will burn you! Don't touch them! Over time, they cool off into a gray color.

tasks.longDescription: The easiest way to hunt these down is the use the map. Look for discolorations and outstanding blocks on the map. Also, you may busy yourself making your moon base first. This will give the meteors time to start showing up nearby. You can use a chunk loader to encourage them to continue generating in a large area while you are away from the moon.

tasks.description: There's A Meteor In My Plate
tasks.longDescription: Time to run this through the gong show--your metal compressor--to get sheets of meteoric iron. You'll be needing a bunch of that as we go here.

quests.name: Glowing With Embarrassment
quests.description: So hey, torches don't work on the moon. It has something to do with there being no oxygen to burn. Try these glowstone torches instead.

tasks.longDescription: Honestly, they kind of stink but they're okay enough for exploration. I recommend using something else like inverted lamps. Look at the moon base quests for one of those.

quests.name: Lamp Champ
quests.description: Those glowstone torches look pathetic. If you want something more akin to the *future* then try these inverted white lamps.

tasks.longDescription: It takes a little bit of glowstone, but it's worth it. This will give you a lamp that will toggle with a redstone signal, by the way. Maybe you don't want that (you don't want that). Stay tuned!
Put that bad boy back in the crafting grid and it will come out inverted! Now it's always-on by default! Now a redstone signal turns it off!

quests.name: As The World Turns
quests.description: You can make a space station in orbit around the Overworld. Whether or not you do this before going to the moon is up to you. However, I would recommend doing the moon stuff first. The moon has hostile baddies, but I think the landscape is more hospitable generally. Also, I would make sure the "All Systems, Go!" quest comes up in this chapter before doing the space station. That being said, go for it. You have to be careful about how you move, because if you fall off, you're getting flung back to the Overworld!

tasks.longDescription: To create the space station, you will need all this in your inventory. These materials will give you a starting platform on which to create your space station. However, this is not everything! You need to also deal with setting up oxygen. That is highlighted with the moon missions, but I will allow it to activate if you complete this quest. However, just take note that it might mention all this moon stuff that you'll ignore.

quests.name: The Gravity Of The Situation
quests.description: You can make your space station spin, which will induce gravity in it. This is really freaky and strange. It will rotate your station, pressing you outward from it, so down is outwards. This means as you go around the station, the magnitude and direction of gravity will vary. Try not to throw up.

tasks.longDescription: You want to set up to 4 of these around your station. It appears you can put them all in one spot on one end of the station. This might require some experimentation. I'll give you three if you make me one. Also--by the way--I can't actually make a quest to test that you actually are in the space station dimension. Each player gets their own dimension, so this quest book cannot track them.

quests.name: Astroturfing
quests.description: Now let's be frank here. The ore generation rate on the Overworld in Baby's First Space Race is really high. The only reason to mine asteroids is *because you can* and that is enough for me! We're going to make ourselves a fun little toy for this exercise. The Astro Miner is another toy you should find out about in your misadventures on Mars. With that plan in hand, you can make one of the craziest things in Galacticraft.

tasks.longDescription: Well, you have to rip these plans out of a Martian dungeon. I am assuming you know this routine now.

You need 5 orion drives for the astro miner. This is by far the toughest ingredient. They are made by cramming together various ores, but I can think of three ores that will bother you in great detail: cheese ore, desh ore, and ilmenite ore. You have to get those from your space adventures.
You know, after all the trouble you've been through, this thing seems really simple to make. Pssst, don't tell the Galacticraft guy that!

If you arrange 8 of these in a 2x2x2 megacube, it will turn into the docking station for the astro miner. The miner will fly out from it, mine, and return to it to drop off what it found. Set it up in the asteroid belt, give it some power from some side or the back, feed it your astro miner, and you should have yourself an asteroid mining operation! These blocks are pretty easy to make. One recipe yields four blocks, and the ingredients are not a huge fuss.

quests.name: Check Out This Rock Music
quests.description: Let's go find us some giant rocks in the asteroid belt. Make sure you have spare fuel, a parachute, teleporter, etc. Actually, this time, I also recommend you have a jetpack of some kind. You are going to be moving around between a bunch of rocks in open space. This can end quote poorly for you if you don't have a way to cross giant gaps with some control! Also, a frying pan is nice when you fly to another asteroid. It lets you quickly swat away the welcoming committee that is usually waiting for you.
prerequisites: The Outer Ring Of My Patience

tasks.longDescription: You're going to need some ilmenite to make orion drives for the astro miner. Five of them, to be exact. If you find one, I'll give you four. I should double-emphasize that digging straight down an asteroid is seriously dangerous business! You also want some good ranged weaponry for when you try to jump onto a new asteroid. Mobs spawn like crazy on to the top of asteroids. Holy hand grenades or somehow getting arrows with knockback will help. Also, a knockback melee weapon when you land on the asteroid will seriously help out. Don't try to use a digital miner for this; it can't detect ilmenite. You're going to have to knock around some asteroids to find this stuff. Finally, YOU NEED SILK TOUCH to mine the ore blocks. You need the complete ore blocks to make the Orion Drives.
